Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Graphene Based Origami and Kirigami Metamaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Graphene-Based Origami and Kirigami Metamaterials

Non-Technical Description: The paper arts of origami and kirigami ('ori' = fold, 'kiri' = cut) provide a powerful framework to design responsive and tunable new materials. For example, a simple series of cuts can turn a sheet of paper into an accordion-like spring, or a sequence of folds can convert it into a swan. Indeed, many biological tissues develop folds and cuts reminiscent of origami and kirigami that endow them with distinct and useful mechanical properties. The seemingly limitless number of forms that can be created speaks to the potential of exploiting such design principles for materials beyond paper. This project will extend these design ideas to the microscale using graphene, an atomically thin two dimensional material, as the nanoscale paper foundation. Lithographic techniques borrowed from the semiconductor industry will be used to pattern the graphene, and a variety of approaches will be employed to create folds, all chosen to realize a specific mechanical property. The focus is on creating mechanical 'metamaterials' - materials whose properties reflect the patterns of folds and cuts rather than the properties of the underlying paper. With room temperature applications in mind, the theoretical effort will focus on the crucial role of thermally-activated Brownian motion in determining the material properties of graphene monolayers with cuts and folds. This paper-arts-inspired strategy has the potential to fundamentally transform the way materials are designed for the micro-world and could find applications in areas ranging from micro-robotics to mechanical sensors and actuators that mimic biologically 'active' tissues.

Technical Description: Using lithographic techniques, graphene sheets will be perforated and cut to create modules with prescribed mechanical properties. These modules will be assembled to create mechanical meta-materials whose response to applied stresses, temperature, and other environmental signals can be tailored. The project focuses on the following interrelated goals: (a) Experimentally testing current predictions for graphene's thermomechanical properties and their dependence on geometry and boundary conditions; (b) Creating a library of mechanically programmable modular units out of cut graphene sheets; (c) Designing meta-materials assembled out of the basic graphene kirigami and origami modules to achieve a particular function; (d) Creating a theory of thermally excited atomically thin membranes with cuts and folds, to guide experiments and improve understanding of the basic principles. These goals will form the cornerstone for building a general-purpose open source design tool that can be used by engineers to assemble materials out of the origami and kirigami based modules, simulate their mechanical properties, and allow for iterative design work flows. This tool will be used to promote rapid materials discovery, development, and property optimization of atomic membrane origami and kirigami metamaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NB: This award was a transfer of a no-cost extension (NCE) from Syracuse University to University of California Santa Barbara. The Syracuse NCE was for the original grant DMREF/Collaborative Research: Graphene Based Origami and Kirigami Metamaterials awarded in 2014. 

Thin materials behave very differently from their more familiar three-dimensional counterparts. If one compares the energy cost of stretching a sheet of dimensions LxL to the energy cost of   bending the same sheet one finds that it grows like (L/t)^2 ? a purely dimensionless number.  And so halving the thickness of a sheet means a four-fold favoring of bending over stretching. This is easily illustrated with A4 paper for which vK ~ 10^6! Now the Moore?s law of thinness for known materials is the atomically-thin carbon sheet molecule known as graphene, with thickness around 2 Angstroms. A 10 micron sheet of graphene has vK ~ 10^12!! vK  for thin-plate elasticity is akin to the dimensionless Reynolds number for fluids. Low bending rigidity corresponds to low viscosity. When graphene is heated the majority of configurations result from bending with very little stretching. Since there are a huge number of available bent configurations (think of a rugged landscape) the entropy of bending for free-standing sheets dominates the statistical behavior. 

The most striking prediction of the technical analysis of such thermalized elastic sheets is that the material parameters (Y and kappa) are no longer fixed numbers but rather length-scale dependent quantities. The bending rigidity in fact grows almost linearly with size L.  And so any desired bending rigidity can be obtained simply by choosing the right size. Controlling the statistical behavior of a system geometrically in this way, as opposed to applying external electromechanical fields, gives an entirely new approach to the design of nano- and micro-electromechanical systems (NEMS and MEMs) that is only just beginning to be investigated and exploited. 

There is a second reason that graphene provides an ideal system to test the statistical mechanics of thermally fluctuating elastic membranes. Its high Young?s modulus means that thermal fluctuations over even small length scales significantly stiffen the renormalized bending rigidity. In contrast for soft materials the effects of thermal fluctuations only set in for scales that are bigger than the sheets themselves and so can never play a significant role. Graphene statistical mechanics is therefore a wonderful example of a system that is simultaneously hard and quantum (atomic bonds) and soft (bending rigidity).

This project undertook and met the challenge of obtaining a precise understanding of the effect of thermal fluctuations on graphene ribbons clamped at one or both ends, including perforations.

We compared our own coarse-grained Molecular Dynamics simulations with known and new analytic predictions of the scaling of width-averaged root-mean-squared height fluctuations as a function of distance along the ribbon. Scaling collapse as a function of W and L also allows us to extract the scaling exponent eta governing the long-wavelength stiffening of the bending rigidity. This understanding of the geometry-dependent mechanical properties of graphene, including arrays of holes and cuts, enables the design of a variety of modular elements with desired mechanical properties starting from pure graphene alone. 

Intellectual Merit: Typically, construction of devices relies on using materials with a variety of mechanical properties. We have shown that one can state with a single platform, graphene, and, using cuts in combination with kirigami and origami principles, tailor emergent mechanical behaviors so that material properties can be designed. This work addresses a major need for materials with tunable mechanical properties for construction of micro- and nano-scale machines. The thermo-mechanical behavior of graphene was elucidated by the development of theoretical techniques for handling strongly coupled, non-linear statistical mechanical systems with complex topology. It directly informs the required fabrication methods and design principles needed to achieve control over the mechanical behavior of folded and/or cut sheets. 

Broader Impact: The numerical codes and recipes used for this project are freely available to the broader scientific community, either as Supplementary Information to journal publications or upon request. In addition, the PI has given talks at all levels from public lectures to colloquia to technical seminars. Overall, these talks have reached out to everyone from non-experts to scientific researchers to policymakers, making them aware of the growing importance and excitement in this research area.

The high profile of the work has prompted NEMS researchers to explore geometric tuning of nanoscale materials. We expect this will inspire others to pursue these lines of investigation as the field is very new. The advantage that other researchers will have is that we have worked out many of the major stumbling blocks for getting specific designs and devices to work. In particular the recipes we have established allow final products to be made very reproducibly. As such we anticipate wide-scale adoption of the methods and techniques we have developed.
